name: places/ChIJTVdrGfNbwokR0Ucx-CyqoIc
formattedAddress: 89 South St, New York, NY 10038, USA
adrFormatAddress: 89 South St, New York, NY 10038, USA

originalText.text: We visited here with the entire family (10 of us!) When it was advertised as Disney's Santa Claus land through New York Bucket Listers. To say it was disappointing would be an understatement. As described in other reviews, the skating rink is not ice but rather UHMW plastic puzzle board. It is really difficult to try and use ice skates on this material especially after it has been used extensively. Staff is lethargic and cares little. There is almost no oversight of what is happening, basically a free-for-all once you get beyond the admission gates. The only food that was available were some hard pretzels and mac and cheese bites at the concession stand. There were no cocktails as advertised just beer and wine. Hot cocoa was okay but you can get that anywhere. Save your money and skip this! If you really want to try it just get the general admission and go up there to take pictures and have a cup of hot cocoa. The view is nice. Perhaps the only saving grace...

originalText.text:
Festive Faux Pas: A Winter Wonderland Debacle

As the holiday season approaches, the allure of winter wonderlands beckons, promising a festive escape from the mundane. However, my recent visit on top a pier left me feeling more like an arctic explorer stuck in a plastic purgatory.

Upon arrival, I was greeted by a rather underwhelming sight: a small, circular expanse of plastic masquerading as an ice rink. The once pristine white surface was now riddled with scratches and scuffs, bearing the marks of countless skates that had valiantly attempted to glide across its resistant surface.

The synthetic ice, I discovered, was not only aesthetically unappealing but also functionally deficient. Instead of the effortless glide one expects from traditional ice, this plastic impostor offered a jerky, halting experience, akin to skating on a bed of pebbles. You get this pleasure all for the cheap price of $20.

The rink's surroundings, while adorned with twinkling lights and faux snow, failed to mask the underlying sense of artificiality. The festive cheer was further dampened by the incessant drone of a generic holiday playlist, which seemed to be on a perpetual loop of 'Jingle Bells' and 'We Wish You a Merry Christmas.

After my somewhat perilous skating adventure, I decided to seek refuge in the restrooms, hoping to find some respite from the plastic purgatory.

Upon entering the restroom, I was immediately greeted by an assault on the senses. The lights flickered erratically, casting an unsettling strobe effect that made me feel like I had stepped into a haunted house. The air was thick with a pungent odor that seemed to blend the smells of stale urine, disinfectant, and something far more unpleasant.

Determined to brave the restroom, I searched for an unoccupied stall. However, each stall I approached revealed a scene of utter chaos. One toilet was continually flushing, another stall was occupied by the source of the odor, a sight that will forever be etched in my memory.

So, unless you have a penchant for synthetic ice, a tolerance for generic holiday tunes, and adventure in a bathroom experience, and a love of trying to have fun because you spent your money already anyway, I would advise only coming here if you want 'meh.'

originalText.text: You will be disappointed if you are thinking date night. This place is for people with young children ( under 9). There is absolutely No Ice! The rink is make out of dirty PCV board. This material cannot be skated on. The hot chocolate was ok but you can get that anywhere. Very disillusioned

text.text: You will be disappointed if you are thinking date night. This place is for people with young children ( under 9). There is absolutely No Ice! The rink is make out of dirty PCV board. This material cannot be skated on. The hot chocolate was ok but you can get that anywhere. Very disillusioned

originalText.text: This place is a scam. Online in pictures I saw that admission and Skate rental is $25 per person.  When me and my boyfriend got there, you could only purchase online. There is no stand for purchases in person. When purchased two tickets it came out to $62. I Figured that was for admission and skate rentals. When we got inside lady told us skate rental was $20 per person. Then the lady tells us it's $60. Their taxing $10 each for each per skate, which basically comes out to $30 per person just fir skates. My boyfriend wasn't having it so he told her that doesn't make sense. He had a $50 dollar bill in his hand. She said it's okay just give me $50. We put on our skates and went out to skate. Realized the ice wasn't even real ice. It's like white cardboard. We were already pissed. We went back inside and asked for a refund and to speak to a Manger. The lady says it's okay I'll just give you your money back. Takes the $50 from under the counter. Like it was just sitting there and she was going to pocket it. Also the slide was closed due to someone breaking their ankle.  Only thing I'll say the free hot chocolate was good and it's a nice place to get some pictures in because of the view. Definitely not worth $120 just to take some pictures. I wouldn't recommend at all.

originalText.text: This is NOT an ice skating rink. Scam. False advertisement . No views of the river while in the plastic rink , disappointed is an understatement.
